brief_summary.textblock:
We hypothesize that patients with untreated OSAS will have more visceral fat, fatty liver
      and increased carotid artery thickness whereas treatment with CPAP may reduce the mesenteric
      and liver fat, plasma lipids, carotid artery thickness.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of CPAP on Visceral Fat Thickness

detailed_description.textblock:
This proposed RCT will compare the effects of therapeutic CPAP versus subtherapeutic CPAP in
      patients newly diagnosed with OSA with reference to visceral fat especially mesenteric fat
      thickness, liver fat, carotid artery IMT, LPW thickness, plasma lipids and adipokines over a
      treatment period of 3 months. The results of this study will advance our understanding of
      the relative role of OSA and obesity in the pathogenesis of MetS and whether CPAP therapy
      can improve these metabolic dysregulation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  symptomatic patients with OSA of AHI >= 5/hr

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Recent or past history of myocardial infarction/stroke/heart failure, unstable
             angina, underlying malignancy,

          -  patients with clinical features of any active infection

          -  those who require urgent CPAP treatment because of associated respiratory failure or
             to prevent job loss through excessive daytime sleepiness (eg professional drivers,
             those handling dangerous machinery)

          -  moderate to severe valvular heart disease, cardiomyopathy, and previous diagnosis of
             OSA and/or previous use of CPAP therapy.

intervention.description: All subjects will undergo ultrasound examination of the abdomen the day after overnight PSG and then at 3 months after completion of therapeutic or subtherapeutic CPAP treatment of 4 cm water.

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Study on the Effects of CPAP on Visceral Fat Thickness, Carotid Intima-media Thickness and Adipokines in Patients With Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Syndrome

oversight_info.authority: Hong Kong: Joint CUHK-NTEC Clinical Research Ethics Committee

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
